scene.scenelocation: Antioch (Syria). A room in the palace.

stagedir.dir: Enter Antiochus, Prince Pericles, and Followers.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Bring in our daughter, clothed like a bride
For embracements even of Jove himself;
At whose conception, till Lucina reigned,
Nature this dowry gave: to glad her presence,
The senate-house of planets all did sit,
To knit in her their best perfections.

scene.line: But my unspotted fire of love to you.
Thus ready for the way of life or death,
I wait the sharpest blow, Antiochus.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Scorning advice, read the conclusion then;
Which read and not expounded, ’tis decreed,
As these before thee, thou thyself shalt bleed.

speech.speaker: DAUGH.
speech.line: Of all ’say’d yet, mayst thou prove prosperous!
Of all ’say’d yet, I wish thee happiness!

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Like a bold champion I assume the lists,
Nor ask advice of any other thought
But faithfulness and courage.
Sharp physic is the last. But O you powers!
That gives heaven countless eyes to view men’s acts,
Why cloud they not their sights perpetually,
If this be true which makes me pale to read it?
Fair glass of light, I lov’d you, and could still,
Were not this glorious casket stor’d with ill.
But I must tell you, now my thoughts revolt,
For he’s no man on whom perfections wait
That, knowing sin within, will touch the gate.
You are a fair viol, and your sense the strings;
Who, finger’d to make man his lawful music,
Would draw heaven down, and all the gods to hearken;
But being play’d upon before your time,
Hell only danceth at so harsh a chime.
Good sooth, I care not for you.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Prince Pericles, touch not, upon thy life,
For that’s an article within our law,
As dangerous as the rest. Your time’s expir’d,
Either expound now, or receive your sentence.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Great King,
Few love to hear the sins they love to act;
’Twould braid yourself too near for me to tell it.
Who has a book of all that monarchs do,
He’s more secure to keep it shut than shown;
For vice repeated is like the wand’ring wind,
Blows dust in others’ eyes, to spread itself;
And yet the end of all is bought thus dear,
The breath is gone, and the sore eyes see clear
To stop the air would hurt them. The blind mole casts
Copp’d hills towards heaven, to tell the earth is throng’d
By man’s oppression, and the poor worm doth die for’t.
Kings are earth’s gods; in vice their law’s their will;
And if Jove stray, who dares say Jove doth ill?
It is enough you know, and it is fit,
What being more known grows worse, to smother it.
All love the womb that their first being bred,
Then give my tongue like leave to love my head.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: How courtesy would seem to cover sin,
When what is done is like an hypocrite,
The which is good in nothing but in sight!
If it be true that I interpret false,
Then were it certain you were not so bad
As with foul incest to abuse your soul;
Where now you’re both a father and a son
By your uncomely claspings with your child
(Which pleasures fits a husband, not a father),
And she an eater of her mother’s flesh
By the defiling of her parent’s bed;
And both like serpents are, who though they feed
On sweetest flowers, yet they poison breed.
Antioch, farewell, for wisdom sees those men
Blush not in actions blacker than the night
Will ’schew no course to keep them from the light.
One sin, I know, another doth provoke:
Murder’s as near to lust as flame to smoke;
Poison and treason are the hands of sin,
Ay, and the targets to put off the shame;
Then lest my life be cropp’d to keep you clear,
By flight I’ll shun the danger which I fear.

speech.speaker: THAL.
speech.line: Doth your Highness call?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Thaliard—you are of our chamber, Thaliard,
And our mind partakes her private actions
To your secrecy; and for your faithfulness
We will advance you, Thaliard. Behold,
Here’s poison and here’s gold; we hate the Prince
Of Tyre, and thou must kill him. It fits thee not
To ask the reason why, because we bid it.
Say, is it done?

speech.speaker: THAL.
speech.line: My lord, ’tis done.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Enough.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: As thou
Wilt live, fly after, and like an arrow shot
From a well-experienc’d archer hits the mark
His eye doth level at, so thou never return
Unless thou say Prince Pericles is dead.

speech.speaker: THAL.
speech.line: My lord,
If I can get him within my pistol’s length,
I’ll make him sure enough; so farewell to your Highness.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Thaliard, adieu!

scene.scenelocation: Tyre. A room in the palace.
scene.line: Why should this change of thoughts,
The sad companion, dull-ey’d melancholy,
Be my so us’d a guest as not an hour
In the day’s glorious walk or peaceful night,
The tomb where grief should sleep, can breed me quiet?
Here pleasures court mine eyes, and mine eyes shun them,
And danger, which I fear’d, is at Antioch,
Whose arm seems far too short to hit me here.
Yet neither pleasure’s art can joy my spirits,
Nor yet the other’s distance comfort me.
Then it is thus: the passions of the mind,
That have their first conception by misdread,
Have after-nourishment and life by care;
And what was first but fear what might be done,
Grows elder now, and cares it be not done.
And so with me: the great Antiochus,
’Gainst whom I am too little to contend,
Since he’s so great can make his will his act,
Will think me speaking, though I swear to silence;
Nor boots it me to say I honor him,
If he suspect I may dishonor him;
And what may make him blush in being known,
He’ll stop the course by which it might be known.
With hostile forces he’ll o’erspread the land,
And with th’ ostent of war will look so huge,
Amazement shall drive courage from the state,
Our men be vanquish’d ere they do resist,
And subjects punish’d that ne’er thought offense:
Which care of them, not pity of myself—
Who am no more but as the tops of trees,
Which fence the roots they grow by and defend them—
Makes both my body pine and soul to languish,
And punish that before that he would punish.

stagedir.dir: Enter Helicanus and all the Lords to Pericles.

scene.line: Helicanus, thou
Hast mov’d us. What seest thou in our looks?

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: An angry brow, dread lord.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: If there be such a dart in princes’ frowns,
How durst thy tongue move anger to our face?

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: How dares the plants look up to heaven, from whence
They have their nourishment?

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Thou knowest I have power
To take thy life from thee.

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: I have ground the axe myself,
Do but you strike the blow.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Rise, prithee rise. Sit down. Thou art
No flatterer. I thank thee for’t, and heaven forbid
That kings should let their ears hear their faults hid!
Fit counsellor and servant for a prince,
Who by thy wisdom makes a prince thy servant,
What wouldst thou have me do?

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: To bear with patience
Such griefs as you yourself do lay upon yourself.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Thou speak’st like a physician, Helicanus,
That ministers a potion unto me
That thou wouldst tremble to receive thyself.
Attend me then: I went to Antioch,
Where, as thou know’st, against the face of death
I sought the purchase of a glorious beauty,
From whence an issue I might propagate,
Are arms to princes and bring joys to subjects.
Her face was to mine eye beyond all wonder;
The rest (hark in thine ear) as black as incest,
Which by my knowledge found, the sinful father
Seem’d not to strike, but smooth. But thou know’st this,
’Tis time to fear when tyrants seems to kiss.
Which fear so grew in me, I hither fled,
Under the covering of a careful night,
Who seem’d my good protector, and being here,
Bethought what was past, what might succeed.
I knew him tyrannous, and tyrants’ fears
Decrease not, but grow faster than the years;
And should he doubt ’t, as no doubt he doth,
That I should open to the list’ning air
How many worthy princes’ bloods were shed
To keep his bed of blackness unlaid ope,
To lop that doubt, he’ll fill this land with arms,
And make pretense of wrong that I have done him;
When all, for mine, if I may call offense,
Must feel war’s blow, who spares not innocence:
Which love to all, of which thyself art one,
Who now reprov’dst me for’t—

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: Alas, sir!

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Drew sleep out of mine eyes, blood from my cheeks,
Musings into my mind, with thousand doubts
How I might stop this tempest ere it came,
And finding little comfort to relieve them,
I thought it princely charity to grieve for them.

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: Well, my lord, since you have given me leave to speak,
Freely will I speak. Antiochus you fear,
And justly too, I think, you fear the tyrant,
Who either by public war or private treason
Will take away your life.
Therefore, my lord, go travel for a while,
Till that his rage and anger be forgot,
Or till the Destinies do cut his thread of life.
Your rule direct to any; if to me,
Day serves not light more faithful than I’ll be.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: I do not doubt thy faith;
But should he wrong my liberties in my absence?

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: We’ll mingle our bloods together in the earth,
From whence we had our being and our birth.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Tyre, I now look from thee then, and to Tharsus
Intend my travel, where I’ll hear from thee,
And by whose letters I’ll dispose myself.
The care I had and have of subjects’ good
On thee I lay, whose wisdom’s strength can bear it.
I’ll take thy word for faith, not ask thine oath:
Who shuns not to break one will crack them both;
But in our orbs we’ll live so round and safe,
That time of both this truth shall ne’er convince,
Thou show’dst a subject’s shine, I a true prince’.

scene.scenelocation: Tyre. An antechamber in the palace.

speech.speaker: THAL.
speech.line: So this is Tyre, and this the court. Here must I kill King Pericles; and if I do it not, I am sure to be hang’d at home. ’Tis dangerous. Well, I perceive he was a wise fellow and had good discretion that, being bid to ask what he would of the king, desir’d he might know none of his secrets. Now do I see he had some reason for’t; for if a king bid a man be a villain, he’s bound by the indenture of his oath to be one. Husht! Here comes the lords of Tyre.

stagedir.dir: Enter Helicanus, Escanes, with other Lords.

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: You shall not need, my fellow peers of Tyre,
Further to question me of your king’s departure.
His seal’d commission, left in trust with me,
Does speak sufficiently he’s gone to travel.

speech.speaker: THAL.
speech.line: What from Antioch?

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: Royal Antiochus, on what cause I know not,
Took some displeasure at him, at lease he judg’d so;
And doubting lest he had err’d or sinn’d,
To show his sorrow, he’d correct himself;
So puts himself unto the shipman’s toil,
With whom each minute threatens life or death.

speech.speaker: THAL.
CLE.
speech.line: My Dionyza, shall we rest us here,
And by relating tales of others’ griefs,
See if ’twill teach us to forget our own?

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: That were to blow at fire in hope to quench it,
For who digs hills because they do aspire
Throws down one mountain to cast up a higher.
O my distressed lord, even such our griefs are;
Here they are but felt, and seen with mischief’s eyes,
But like to groves, being topp’d, they higher rise.

speech.speaker: CLE.
speech.line: O Dionyza!
Who wanteth food and will not say he wants it,
Or can conceal his hunger till he famish?
Our tongues and sorrows to sound deep our woes
Into the air, our eyes to weep, till tongues
Fetch breath that may proclaim them louder, that
If heaven slumber, while their creatures want,
They may awake their helpers to comfort them.
I’ll then discourse our woes, felt several years,
And wanting breath to speak, help me with tears.

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: I’ll do my best, sir.

speech.speaker: CLE.
speech.line: This Tharsus, o’er which I have the government,
A city on whom plenty held full hand,
For riches strew’d herself even in her streets;
Whose towers bore heads so high they kiss’d the clouds,
And strangers ne’er beheld but wond’red at;
Whose men and dames so jetted and adorn’d,
Like one another’s glass to trim them by;
Their tables were stor’d full, to glad the sight,
And not so much to feed on as delight;
All poverty was scorn’d, and pride so great,
The name of help grew odious to repeat.

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: O, ’tis too true.

speech.speaker: CLE.
speech.line: But see what heaven can do by this our change:
These mouths who, but of late, earth, sea, and air
Were all too little to content and please,
Although they gave their creatures in abundance,
As houses are defil’d for want of use,
They are now starv’d for want of exercise;
Those palates who, not yet two summers younger,
Must have inventions to delight the taste,
Would now be glad of bread and beg for it;
Those mothers who, to nousle up their babes,
Thought nought too curious, are ready now
To eat those little darlings whom they lov’d.
So sharp are hunger’s teeth, that man and wife
Draw lots who first shall die to lengthen life.
Here stands a lord, and there a lady weeping;
Here many sink, yet those which see them fall
Have scarce strength left to give them burial.
Is not this true?

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: Our cheeks and hollow eyes do witness it.

speech.speaker: CLE.
speech.line: O, let those cities that of plenty’s cup
And her prosperities so largely taste,
With their superfluous riots, hear these tears!
The misery of Tharsus may be theirs.

speech.speaker: CLE.
speech.line: Welcome is peace, if he on peace consist;
If wars, we are unable to resist.

stagedir.dir: Enter Pericles with Lord and Attendants.

speech.speaker: GOW.
speech.line: Here have you seen a mighty king
His child, I wis, to incest bring;
A better prince and benign lord,
That will prove aweful both in deed and word.
Be quiet then, as men should be,
Till he hath pass’d necessity.
I’ll show you those in troubles reign,
Losing a mite, a mountain gain.
The good in conversation,
To whom I give my benison,
Is still at Tharsus, where each man
Thinks all is writ he speken can;
And, to remember what he does,
Build his statue to make him glorious.
But tidings to the contrary
Are brought your eyes; what need speak I?

stagedir.dir: Enter at one door Pericles talking with Cleon; all the Train with them. Enter at another door the First Tyrian Messenger with a letter to Pericles. Pericles shows the letter to Cleon. Pericles gives the Messenger a reward and knights him. Exit Pericles at one door and Cleon at another.

scene.scenelocation: Pentapolis. An open place by the seaside.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Yet cease your ire, you angry stars of heaven!
Wind, rain, and thunder, remember earthly man
Is but a substance that must yield to you;
And I (as fits my nature) do obey you.
Alas, the seas hath cast me on the rocks,
Wash’d me from shore to shore, and left me breath
Nothing to think on but ensuing death.
Let it suffice the greatness of your powers
To have bereft a prince of all his fortunes;
And having thrown him from your wat’ry grave,
Here to have death in peace is all he’ll crave.

scene.line: A pretty moral.

speech.speaker: 3. FISH.
speech.line: But, master, if I had been the sexton, I would have been that day in the belfry.

speech.speaker: 2. FISH.
speech.line: Why, man?

speech.speaker: 3. FISH.
speech.line: Because he should have swallow’d me too, and when I had been in his belly, I would have kept such a jangling of the bells, that he should never have left till he cast bells, steeple, church, and parish up again. But if the good King Simonides were of my mind—

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Simonides?

speech.speaker: 3. FISH.
speech.line: We would purge the land of these drones, that rob the bee of her honey.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: How from the finny subject of the sea
These fishers tell the infirmities of men,
And from their wat’ry empire recollect
All that may men approve or men detect!—
Peace be at your labor, honest fishermen.

speech.speaker: 2. FISH.
speech.line: Honest, good fellow, what’s that? If it be a day fits you, search out of the calendar, and nobody look after it.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: May see the sea hath cast upon your coast—

speech.speaker: 2. FISH.
speech.line: What a drunken knave was the sea to cast thee in our way!

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: A man whom both the waters and the wind,
In that vast tennis-court, hath made the ball
For them to play upon, entreats you pity him.
He asks of you that never us’d to beg.

speech.speaker: 1. FISH.
speech.line: No, friend, cannot you beg? Here’s them in our country of Greece gets more with begging than we can do with working.

speech.speaker: 2. FISH.
speech.line: Canst thou catch any fishes then?

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: I never practic’d it.

speech.speaker: 2. FISH.
speech.line: Nay then thou wilt starve sure; for here’s nothing to be got now-a-days unless thou canst fish for’t.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: What I have been I have forgot to know,
But what I am, want teaches me to think on:
A man throng’d up with cold, my veins are chill
And have no more of life than may suffice
To give my tongue that heat to ask your help;
Which if you shall refuse, when I am dead,
For that I am a man, pray you see me buried.

speech.speaker: 1. FISH.
speech.line: Die, keth ’a? Now gods forbid’t, and I have a gown here! Come put it on, keep thee warm. Now, afore me, a handsome fellow! Come, thou shalt go home, and we’ll have flesh for holidays, fish for fasting-days, and, moreo’er, puddings and flapjacks, and thou shalt be welcome.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: I thank you, sir.

speech.speaker: 2. FISH.
speech.line: Hark you, my friend. You said you could not beg?

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: I did but crave.

speech.speaker: 2. FISH.
speech.line: But crave? Then I’ll turn craver too, and so I shall scape whipping.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Why, are your beggars whipt then?

speech.speaker: 2. FISH.
speech.line: O, not all, my friend, not all; for if all your beggars were whipt, I would wish no better office than to be beadle. But, master, I’ll go draw up the net.
How well this honest mirth becomes their labor!

speech.speaker: 1. FISH.
speech.line: Hark you, sir; do you know where ye are?

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Not well.

speech.speaker: 1. FISH.
speech.line: Why, I’ll tell you. This is call’d Pentapolis, and our king the good Simonides.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: The good Simonides, do you call him?

speech.speaker: 1. FISH.
speech.line: Ay, sir, and he deserves so to be call’d for his peaceable reign and good government.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: He is a happy king, since he gains from his subjects the name of good by his government. How far is his court distant from this shore?

speech.speaker: 1. FISH.
speech.line: Marry, sir, half a day’s journey. And I’ll tell you, he hath a fair daughter, and tomorrow is her birthday, and there are princes and knights come from all parts of the world to just and tourney for her love.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Were my fortunes equal to my desires, I could wish to make one there.

speech.speaker: 1. FISH.
speech.line: O, sir, things must be as they may; and what a man cannot get, he may lawfully deal for his wive’s soul.

stagedir.dir: Enter the two other Fishermen drawing up a net.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Are the knights ready to begin the triumph?

speech.speaker: 1. LORD. PENT.
speech.line: They are, my liege,
And stay your coming to present themselves.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Return them, we are ready; and our daughter here,
In honor of whose birth these triumphs are,
Sits here like beauty’s child, whom nature gat
For men to see, and seeing wonder at.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Knights,
To say you’re welcome were superfluous.
To place upon the volume of your deeds,
As in a title-page, your worth in arms,
Were more than you expect, or more than’s fit,
Since every worth in show commends itself.
Prepare for mirth, for mirth becomes a feast.
You are princes and my guests.

speech.speaker: THAI.
speech.line: But you, my knight and guest,
To whom this wreath of victory I give,
And crown you king of this day’s happiness.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: ’Tis more by fortune, lady, than my merit.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Call it by what you will, the day is your,
And here, I hope, is none that envies it.
In framing an artist, art hath thus decreed,
To make some good, but others to exceed,
And you are her labor’d scholar. Come, queen a’ th’ feast—
For, daughter, so you are—here take your place.
By Jove, I wonder, that is king of thoughts,
These cates resist me, he not thought upon.

speech.speaker: THAI.
speech.line: Sure he’s a gallant gentleman.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: To me he seems like diamond to glass.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Yon king’s to me like to my father’s picture,
Which tells me in that glory once he was;
Had princes sit like stars about his throne,
And he the sun for them to reverence;
None that beheld him but, like lesser lights,
Did vail their crowns to his supremacy;
Where now his son’s like a glow-worm in the night,
The which hath fire in darkness, none in light:
Whereby I see that Time’s the king of men,
He’s both their parent, and he is their grave,
And gives them what he will, not what they crave.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: What, are you merry, knights?

speech.speaker: ALL KNIGHTS.
speech.line: Who can be other in this royal presence?

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Here, with a cup that’s stor’d unto the brim—
As do you love, fill to your mistress’ lips—
We drink this health to you.

speech.speaker: ALL KNIGHTS.
speech.line: We thank your Grace.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Yet pause awhile,
Yon knight doth sit too melancholy,
As if the entertainment in our court
Had not a show might countervail his worth.
Note it not you, Thaisa?

speech.speaker: THAI.
speech.line: What is’t
To me, my father?

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: O, attend, my daughter:
Princes in this should live like gods above,
Who freely give to every one that come
To honor them;
And princes not doing so are like to gnats,
Which make a sound, but kill’d are wond’red at.
Therefore to make his entrance more sweet,
Here, say we drink this standing-bowl of wine to him.

speech.speaker: THAI.
speech.line: Alas, my father, it befits not me
Unto a stranger knight to be so bold.
He may my proffer take for an offense,
Since men take women’s gifts for impudence.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: How?
Do as I bid you, or you’ll move me else.

speech.speaker: THAI.
speech.line: Now by the gods, he could not please me better.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: And furthermore tell him, we desire to know of him
Of whence he is, his name, and parentage.

speech.speaker: THAI.
speech.line: The King my father, sir, has drunk to you—

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: I thank him.

speech.speaker: THAI.
speech.line: Wishing it so much blood unto your life.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: I thank both him and you, and pledge him freely.

speech.speaker: THAI.
speech.line: And further, he desires to know of you
Of whence you are, your name, and parentage.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: A gentleman of Tyre, my name, Pericles,
My education been in arts and arms;
Who, looking for adventures in the world,
Was by the rough seas reft of ships and men,
And after shipwrack driven upon this shore.

speech.speaker: THAI.
speech.line: He thanks your Grace; names himself Pericles,
A gentleman of Tyre,
Who only by misfortune of the seas
Bereft of ships and men, cast on this shore.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Now by the gods, I pity his misfortune,
And will awake him from his melancholy.
Come, gentlemen, we sit too long on trifles,
And waste the time, which looks for other revels.
Even in your armors, as you are address’d,
Will well become a soldier’s dance.
I will not have excuse with saying this,
Loud music is too harsh for ladies’ heads,
Since they love men in arms as well as beds.
Unclasp, unclasp:
Thanks, gentlemen, to all, all have done well;
Yours, sir,
We have given order be next our own.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: I am at your Grace’s pleasure.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Princes, it is too late to talk of love,
And that’s the mark I know you level at.
Therefore each one betake him to his rest;
Tomorrow all for speeding do their best.

scene.scenelocation: Tyre. A room in the Governor’s house.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD. TYRE.
speech.line: See, not a man in private conference
Or council has respect with him but he.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD. TYRE.
speech.line: It shall no longer grieve without reproof.

speech.speaker: 3. LORD. TYRE.
speech.line: And curs’d be he that will not second it.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD. TYRE.
speech.line: Follow me then. Lord Helicane, a word.

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: With me? And welcome. Happy day, my lords.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD. TYRE.
speech.line: Know that our griefs are risen to the top,
And now at length they overflow their banks.

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: Your griefs, for what? Wrong not your prince you love.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD. TYRE.
speech.line: Wrong not yourself then, noble Helicane;
But if the Prince do live, let us salute him,
Or know what ground’s made happy by his breath.
If in the world he live, we’ll seek him out;
If in his grave he rest, we’ll find him there;
And be resolved he lives to govern us,
Or dead, give ’s cause to mourn his funeral,
And leave us to our free election.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD. TYRE.
speech.line: Whose death indeed the strongest in our censure,
And knowing this kingdom is without a head—
Like goodly buildings left without a roof
Soon fall to ruin—your noble self,
That best know how to rule and how to reign,
We thus submit unto—our sovereign.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Live, noble Helicane!

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: Try honor’s cause; forbear your suffrages.
If that you love Prince Pericles, forbear.
Take I your wish, I leap into the seas,
Where’s hourly trouble for a minute’s ease.
A twelvemonth longer let me entreat you
To forbear the absence of your king;
If in which time expir’d he not return,
I shall with aged patience bear your yoke.
But if I cannot win you to this love,
Go search like nobles, like noble subjects,
And in your search spend your adventurous worth;
Whom if you find, and win unto return,
You shall like diamonds sit about his crown.

speech.speaker: 1. LORD. TYRE.
speech.line: To wisdom he’s a fool that will not yield;
And since Lord Helicane enjoineth us,
We with our travels will endeavor.

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: Then you love us, we you, and we’ll clasp hands:
When peers thus knit, a kingdom ever stands.

scene.scenelocation: Pentapolis. A room in the palace.

stagedir.dir: Enter the King Simonides, reading of a letter, at one door; the Knights meet him.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: So,
They are well dispatch’d; now to my daughter’s letter.
She tells me here, she’ll wed the stranger knight,
Or never more to view nor day nor light.
’Tis well, mistress, your choice agrees with mine;
I like that well. Nay, how absolute she’s in’t,
Not minding whether I dislike or no!
Well, I do commend her choice,
And will no longer have it be delayed.
Soft, here he comes, I must dissemble it.

scene.line: What’s here?
A letter that she loves the knight of Tyre!
’Tis the King’s subtilty to have my life.—
O, seek not to entrap me, gracious lord,
A stranger and distressed gentleman,
That never aim’d so high to love your daughter,
But bent all offices to honor her.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Thou hast bewitch’d my daughter, and thou art
A villain.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: By the gods, I have not.
Never did thought of mine levy offense;
Nor never did my actions yet commence
A deed might gain her love or your displeasure.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Traitor, thou liest.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Traitor?

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Ay, traitor.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Even in his throat—unless it be the King—
That calls me traitor, I return the lie.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Now by the gods, I do applaud his courage.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: My actions are as noble as my thoughts,
That never relish’d of a base descent.
I came unto your court for honor’s cause,
And not to be a rebel to her state;
And he that otherwise accounts of me,
This sword shall prove he’s honor’s enemy.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: No?
Here comes my daughter, she can witness it.

scene.line: I am glad on’t with all my heart.—
I’ll tame you; I’ll bring you in subjection.
Will you, not having my consent,
Bestow your love and your affections
Upon a stranger?

speech.speaker: GOW.
speech.line: Now sleep yslacked hath the rout,
No din but snores the house about,
Made louder by the o’erfed breast
Of this most pompous marriage-feast.
The cat, with eyne of burning coal,
Now couches from the mouse’s hole;
And crickets sing at the oven’s mouth,
Are the blither for their drouth.
Hymen hath brought the bride to bed,
Where, by the loss of maidenhead,
A babe is moulded. Be attent,
And time that is so briefly spent
With your fine fancies quaintly eche:
What’s dumb in show I’ll plain with speech.

stagedir.dir: Enter Pericles and Simonides, at one door, with Attendants. The Second Tyrian Messenger meets them, kneels, and gives Pericles a letter. Pericles shows it Simonides; the Lords kneel to him. Then enter Thaisa with child, with Lychorida, a nurse. The King shows her the letter; she rejoices. She and Pericles take leave of her father, and depart with Lychorida and their Attendants. Then exeunt Simonides and the rest.

speech.speaker: LYC.
speech.line: Here is a thing too young for such a place,
Who, if it had conceit, would die, as I
Am like to do. Take in your arms this piece
Of your dead queen.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: How? How, Lychorida?

speech.speaker: LYC.
speech.line: Patience, good sir, do not assist the storm.
Here’s all that is left living of your queen:
A little daughter. For the sake of it
Be manly, and take comfort.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: O you gods!
Why do you make us love your goodly gifts
And snatch them straight away? We here below
Recall not what we give, and therein may
Use honor with you.

speech.speaker: LYC.
speech.line: Patience, good sir,
Even for this charge.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Now, mild may be thy life!
For a more blusterous birth had never babe.
Quiet and gentle thy conditions! For
Thou art the rudeliest welcome to this world
That ever was prince’s child. Happy what follows!
Thou hast as chiding a nativity
As fire, air, water, earth, and heaven can make
To herald thee from the womb. Even at the first
Thy loss is more than can thy portage quit
With all thou canst find here. Now the good gods
Throw their best eyes upon’t!

speech.speaker: 2. SAIL.
speech.line: Sir, we have a chest beneath the hatches, caulk’d and bitum’d ready.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: I thank thee. Mariner, say, what coast is this?

speech.speaker: 2. SAIL.
speech.line: We are near Tharsus.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Thither, gentle mariner,
Alter thy course for Tyre. When canst thou reach it?

speech.speaker: 1. SAIL.
speech.line: By break of day, if the wind cease.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: O, make for Tharsus!
There will I visit Cleon, for the babe
Cannot hold out to Tyrus. There I’ll leave it
At careful nursing. Go thy ways, good mariner,
I’ll bring the body presently.

scene.scenelocation: Ephesus. A room in Cerimon’s house.

stagedir.dir: Enter Lord Cerimon with an Ephesan Servant and another Man, both storm-beaten.

speech.speaker: PHIL.
speech.line: Doth my lord call?

speech.speaker: CER.
speech.line: Get fire and meat for these poor men.
Give this to the pothecary,
And tell me how it works.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Ephesan Servant and other Man.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT. EPH.
speech.line: Good morrow.

speech.speaker: 2. GENT. EPH.
speech.line: Good morrow to your lordship.

speech.speaker: CER.
speech.line: Gentlemen,
Why do you stir so early?

speech.speaker: 1. GENT. EPH.
speech.line: Sir,
Our lodgings, standing bleak upon the sea,
Shook as the earth did quake;
The very principals did seem to rend,
And all to topple. Pure surprise and fear
Made me to quit the house.

speech.speaker: 2. GENT. EPH.
speech.line: That is the cause we trouble you so early,
’Tis not our husbandry.

speech.speaker: CER.
speech.line: O, you say well.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT. EPH.
speech.line: But I much marvel that your lordship, having
Rich tire about you, should at these early hours
Shake off the golden slumber of repose.
’Tis most strange
Nature should be so conversant with pain,
Being thereto not compelled.

speech.speaker: CER.
speech.line: I hold it ever
Virtue and cunning were endowments greater
Than nobleness and riches. Careless heirs
May the two latter darken and expend;
But immortality attends the former,
Making a man a god. ’Tis known, I ever
Have studied physic; through which secret art,
By turning o’er authorities, I have,
Together with my practice, made familiar
To me and to my aid the blest infusions
That dwells in vegetives, in metals, stones;
And can speak of the disturbances
That nature works, and of her cures; which doth give me
A more content in course of true delight
Than to be thirsty after tottering honor,
Or tie my pleasure up in silken bags,
To please the fool and death.

speech.speaker: 2. GENT. EPH.
speech.line: Your honor has through Ephesus pour’d forth
Your charity, and hundreds call themselves
Your creatures, who by you have been restored;
And not your knowledge, your personal pain, but even
Your purse, still open, hath built Lord Cerimon
Such strong renown as time shall never—

stagedir.dir: Enter two or three of Cerimon’s Servants with a chest.

line.recite: If e’er this coffin drives a-land,
This queen, worth all our mundane cost.
Who finds her, give her burying,
She was the daughter of a king.
Besides this treasure for a fee,

scene.line: If thou livest, Pericles, thou hast a heart
That ever cracks for woe! This chanc’d tonight.

speech.speaker: 2. GENT. EPH.
speech.line: Most likely, sir.

speech.speaker: CER.
speech.line: Nay, certainly tonight,
For look how fresh she looks! They were too rough
That threw her in the sea. Make a fire within.
Fetch hither all my boxes in my closet.
Well said, well said. The fire and cloths.
The rough and woeful music that we have,
Cause it to sound, beseech you.
The vial once more. How thou stir’st, thou block!
The music there! I pray you give her air.
Gentlemen, this queen will live. Nature awakes,
A warmth breathes out of her. She hath not been
Entranc’d above five hours. See how she gins
To blow into life’s flower again!

speech.speaker: 1. GENT. EPH.
speech.line: The heavens,
Through you, increase our wonder, and sets up
Your fame forever.

speech.speaker: CER.
speech.line: She is alive; behold
Her eyelids, cases to those heavenly jewels
Which Pericles hath lost, begin to part
Their fringes of bright gold. The diamonds
Of a most praised water doth appear,
To make the world twice rich. Live, and make
Us weep to hear your fate, fair creature,
Rare as you seem to be.

speech.speaker: THAI.
speech.line: O dear Diana,
Where am I? Where’s my lord? What world is this?

speech.speaker: 2. GENT. EPH.
speech.line: Is not this strange?

speech.speaker: 1. GENT. EPH.
speech.line: Most rare.

speech.speaker: CER.
speech.line: Hush, my gentle neighbors!
Lend me your hands. To the next chamber bear her.
Get linen. Now this matter must be look’d to,
For her relapse is mortal. Come, come;
And Aesculapius guide us!

stagedir.dir: They carry her away. Exeunt omnes.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Most honor’d Cleon, I must needs be gone.
My twelve months are expir’d, and Tyrus stands
In a litigious peace. You and your lady
Take from my heart all thankfulness! The gods
Make up the rest upon you!

speech.speaker: CLE.
speech.line: Your shakes of fortune, though they haunt you mortally,
Yet glance full wond’ringly on us.

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: O your sweet queen!
That the strict fates had pleas’d you had brought her hither
To have blest mine eyes with her!

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: We cannot but obey
The powers above us. Could I rage and roar
As doth the sea she lies in, yet the end
Must be as ’tis. My gentle babe Marina, whom,
For she was born at sea, I have nam’d so, here
I charge your charity withal; leaving her
The infant of your care, beseeching you
To give her princely training, that she may be
Manner’d as she is born.

speech.speaker: CLE.
speech.line: Fear not, my lord, but think
Your Grace, that fed my country with your corn,
For which the people’s prayers still fall upon you,
Must in your child be thought on. If neglection
Should therein make me vile, the common body,
By you reliev’d, would force me to my duty;
But if to that my nature need a spur,
The gods revenge it upon me and mine
To the end of generation!

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: I believe you,
Your honor and your goodness teach me to’t
Without your vows. Till she be married, madam,
By bright Diana, whom we honor, all
Unscissor’d shall this hair of mine remain,
Though I show ill in’t. So I take my leave.
Good madam, make me blessed in your care
In bringing up my child.

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: I have one myself,
Who shall not be more dear to my respect
Than yours, my lord.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Madam, my thanks and prayers.

speech.speaker: CLE.
speech.line: We’ll bring your Grace e’en to the edge a’ th’ shore,
Then give you up to the mask’d Neptune and
The gentlest winds of heaven.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: I will embrace
Your offer. Come, dearest madam. O, no tears,
Lychorida, no tears.
Look to your little mistress, on whose grace
You may depend hereafter. Come, my lord.

scene.scenelocation: Ephesus. A room in Cerimon’s house.

speech.speaker: GOW.
speech.line: Imagine Pericles arriv’d at Tyre,
Welcom’d and settled to his own desire.
His woeful queen we leave at Ephesus,
Unto Diana there ’s a votaress.
Now to Marina bend your mind,
Whom our fast-growing scene must find
At Tharsus, and by Cleon train’d
In music’s letters, who hath gain’d
Of education all the grace,
Which makes her both th’ heart and place
Of general wonder. But alack,
That monster Envy, oft the wrack
Of earned praise, Marina’s life
Seeks to take off by treason’s knife,
And in this kind: our Cleon hath
One daughter, and a full-grown wench,
Even ripe for marriage rite; this maid
Hight Philoten, and it is said
For certain in our story, she
Would ever with Marina be:
Be’t when they weav’d the sleided silk
With fingers long, small, white as milk;
Or when she would with sharp needle wound
The cambric, which she made more sound
By hurting it; or when to th’ lute
She sung, and made the night-bird mute,
That still records with moan; or when
She would with rich and constant pen
Vail to her mistress Dian; still
This Philoten contends in skill
With absolute Marina: so
The dove of Paphos might with the crow
Vie feathers white. Marina gets
All praises, which are paid as debts,
And not as given. This so darks
In Philoten all graceful marks,
That Cleon’s wife, with envy rare,
A present murderer does prepare
For good Marina, that her daughter
Might stand peerless by this slaughter.
The sooner her vile thoughts to stead,
Lychorida, our nurse, is dead,
And cursed Dionyza hath
The pregnant instrument of wrath
Prest for this blow. The unborn event
I do commend to your content;
Only I carried winged time
Post on the lame feet of my rhyme,
Which never could I so convey,
Unless your thoughts went on my way.
Dionyza does appear,
With Leonine, a murderer.

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: Thy oath remember, thou hast sworn to do’t.
’Tis but a blow, which never shall be known.
Thou canst not do a thing in the world so soon
To yield thee so much profit. Let not conscience,
Which is but cold in flaming, thy lone bosom
Inflame too nicely, nor let pity, which
Even women have cast off, melt thee, but be
A soldier to thy purpose.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: I will do’t, but yet she is a goodly creature.

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: The fitter then the gods should have her.
Here she comes weeping for her only mistress’ death.
Thou art resolv’d?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: I am resolv’d.

stagedir.dir: Enter Marina with a basket of flowers.

scene.line: Is this wind westerly that blows?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: South-west.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: When I was born, the wind was north.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Was’t so?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: My father, as nurse says, did never fear,
But cried “Good seamen!” to the sailors, galling
His kingly hands haling ropes,
And clasping to the mast, endur’d a sea
That almost burst the deck.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: When was this?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: When I was born.
Never was waves nor wind more violent,
And from the ladder-tackle washes off
A canvas-climber. “Ha!” says one, “wolt out?”
And with a dropping industry they skip
From stem to stern. The boatswain whistles, and
The master calls, and trebles their confusion.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Come say your prayers.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: What mean you?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: If you require a little space for prayer,
I grant it. Pray, but be not tedious, for
The gods are quick of ear, and I am sworn
To do my work with haste.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Why will you kill me?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: To satisfy my lady.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Why would she have me kill’d now?
As I can remember, by my troth,
I never did her hurt in all my life.
I never spake bad word, nor did ill turn
To any living creature. Believe me law,
I never kill’d a mouse, nor hurt a fly;
I trod upon a worm against my will,
But I wept for’t. How have I offended,
Wherein my death might yield her any profit,
Or my life imply her any danger?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: My commission
Is not to reason of the deed, but do’t.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: You will not do’t for all the world, I hope.
You are well-favored, and your looks foreshow
You have a gentle heart. I saw you lately
When you caught hurt in parting two that fought;
Good sooth, it show’d well in you. Do so now.
Your lady seeks my life, come you between,
And save poor me, the weaker.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: I am sworn,
And will dispatch.

speech.speaker: 2. PIRATE.
speech.line: A prize, a prize!

speech.speaker: 3. PIRATE.
speech.line: Half-part, mates, half-part. Come, let’s have her aboard suddenly.

stagedir.dir: Exit Marina dragged out by the Pirates.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: These roguing thieves serve the great pirate Valdes,
And they have seiz’d Marina. Let her go!
There’s no hope she will return. I’ll swear she’s dead,
And thrown into the sea. But I’ll see further:
Perhaps they will but please themselves upon her,
Not carry her aboard. If she remain,
Whom they have ravish’d must by me be slain.

speech.speaker: PAND.
speech.line: Boult!

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: Sir?

speech.speaker: PAND.
speech.line: Search the market narrowly, Mytilene is full of gallants. We lost too much money this mart by being too wenchless.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: We were never so much out of creatures. We have but poor three, and they can do no more than they can do; and they with continual action are even as good as rotten.

speech.speaker: PAND.
speech.line: Therefore let’s have fresh ones, what e’er we pay for them. If there be not a conscience to be us’d in every trade, we shall never prosper.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: Thou say’st true. ’Tis not our bringing up of poor bastards—as I think, I have brought up some eleven—

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: Ay, to eleven, and brought them down again. But shall I search the market?

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: What else, man? The stuff we have, a strong wind will blow it to pieces, they are so pitifully sodden.

speech.speaker: PAND.
speech.line: Thou sayest true, there’s two unwholesome, a’ conscience. The poor Transylvanian is dead that lay with the little baggage.

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: Ay, she quickly poop’d him, she made him roast-meat for worms. But I’ll go search the market.

speech.speaker: PAND.
speech.line: Three or four thousand chequins were as pretty a proportion to live quietly, and so give over.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: Why to give over, I pray you? Is it a shame to get when we are old?

speech.speaker: PAND.
speech.line: O, our credit comes not in like the commodity, nor the commodity wages not with the danger; therefore if in our youths we could pick up some pretty estate, ’twere not amiss to keep our door hatch’d. Besides, the sore terms we stand upon with the gods will be strong with us for giving o’er.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: Come, other sorts offend as well as we.

speech.speaker: PAND.
speech.line: As well as we! Ay, and better too; we offend worse. Neither is our profession any trade, it’s no calling. But here comes Boult.

stagedir.dir: Enter Boult with the Pirates and Marina.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: Boult, take you the marks of her, the color of her hair, complexion, height, her age, with warrant of her virginity, and cry, “He that will give most shall have her first.” Such a maidenhead were no cheap thing, if men were as they have been. Get this done as I command you.

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: Performance shall follow.

scene.line: Now, sir, hast thou cried her through the market?

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: I have cried her almost to the number of her hairs, I have drawn her picture with my voice.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: And I prithee tell me, how dost thou find the inclination of the people, especially of the younger sort?

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: Faith, they listen’d to me as they would have hearken’d to their father’s testament. There was a Spaniard’s mouth wat’red, and he went to bed to her very description.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: We shall have him here tomorrow with his best ruff on.

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: Tonight, tonight. But, mistress, do you know the French knight that cow’rs i’ the hams?

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: Who, Monsieur Verollus?

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: Ay, he, he offer’d to cut a caper at the proclamation, but he made a groan at it, and swore he would see her tomorrow.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: Well, well, as for him, he brought his disease hither; here he does but repair it. I know he will come in our shadow, to scatter his crowns in the sun.

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: Well, if we had of every nation a traveller, we should lodge them with this sign.

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: Why are you foolish? Can it be undone?

speech.speaker: CLE.
speech.line: O Dionyza, such a piece of slaughter
The sun and moon ne’er look’d upon!

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: I think you’ll turn a child again.

speech.speaker: CLE.
speech.line: Were I chief lord of all this spacious world,
I’d give it to undo the deed. O lady,
Much less in blood than virtue, yet a princess
To equal any single crown a’ th’ earth
I’ th’ justice of compare! O villain Leonine!
Whom thou hast pois’ned too.
If thou hadst drunk to him, ’t ’ad been a kindness
Becoming well thy fact. What canst thou say
When noble Pericles shall demand his child?

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: That she is dead. Nurses are not the fates,
To foster it, not ever to preserve.
She died at night; I’ll say so. Who can cross it?
Unless you play the pious innocent,
And for an honest attribute cry out,
“She died by foul play.”

speech.speaker: CLE.
speech.line: O, go to. Well, well,
Of all the faults beneath the heavens, the gods
Do like this worst.

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: Be one of those that thinks
The petty wrens of Tharsus will fly hence
And open this to Pericles. I do shame
To think of what a noble strain you are,
And of how coward a spirit.

speech.speaker: CLE.
speech.line: To such proceeding
Who ever but his approbation added,
Though not his prime consent, he did not flow
From honorable courses.

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: Be it so then,
Yet none does know but you how she came dead,
Nor none can know, Leonine being gone.
She did distain my child, and stood between
Her and her fortunes. None would look on her,
But cast their gazes on Marina’s face;
Whilest ours was blurted at and held a mawkin
Not worth the time of day. It pierc’d me thorough,
And though you call my course unnatural,
You not your child well loving, yet I find
It greets me as an enterprise of kindness
Perform’d to your sole daughter.

speech.speaker: CLE.
speech.line: Heavens forgive it!

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: And as for Pericles,
What should he say? We wept after her hearse,
And yet we mourn. Her monument
Is almost finished, and her epitaphs
In glitt’ring golden characters express
A general praise to her, and care in us
At whose expense ’tis done.

speech.speaker: CLE.
speech.line: Thou art like the harpy,
Which to betray, dost with thine angel’s face
Seize with thine eagle’s talents.

speech.speaker: DION.
speech.line: Y’ are like one that superstitiously
Do swear to th’ gods that winter kills the flies,
But yet I know you’ll do as I advise.

scene.scenelocation: Tarsus. Before the tomb of Marina.

stagedir.dir: Enter Gower before the monument of Marina at Tharsus.

scene.line: See how belief may suffer by foul show!
This borrowed passion stands for true old woe;
And Pericles, in sorrow all devour’d,
With sighs shot through and biggest tears o’ershow’r’d,
Leaves Tharsus and again embarks. He swears
Never to wash his face, nor cut his hairs;
He puts on sackcloth, and to sea. He bears
A tempest, which his mortal vessel tears,
And yet he rides it out. Now please you wit
The epitaph is for Marina writ
By wicked Dionyza.

stagedir.dir: Reads the inscription on Marina’s monument.

scene.scenelocation: Mytilene. A street before the brothel.

speech.speaker: PAND.
speech.line: Well, I had rather than twice the worth of her she had ne’er come here.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: Fie, fie upon her, she’s able to freeze the god Priapus, and undo a whole generation. We must either get her ravish’d or be rid of her. When she should do for clients her fitment, and do me the kindness of our profession, she has me her quirks, her reasons, her master reasons, her prayers, her knees, that she would make a puritan of the devil, if he should cheapen a kiss of her.

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: Faith, I must ravish her, or she’ll disfurnish us of all our cavalleria, and make our swearers priests.

speech.speaker: PAND.
speech.line: Now the pox upon her green-sickness for me!

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: Faith, there’s no way to be rid on’t but by the way to the pox. Here comes the Lord Lysimachus disguis’d.

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: We should have both lord and lown, if the peevish baggage would but give way to customers.

speech.speaker: LYS.
speech.line: That dignifies the renown of a bawd, no less than it gives a good report to a number to be chaste.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: Here comes that which grows to the stalk, never pluck’d yet, I can assure you.
First, I would have you note, this is an honorable man.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: I desire to find him so, that I may worthily note him.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: Next, he’s the governor of this country, and a man whom I am bound to.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: If he govern the country, you are bound to him indeed, but how honorable he is in that, I know not.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: Pray you, without any more virginal fencing, will you use him kindly? He will line your apron with gold.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: What he will do graciously, I will thankfully receive.

speech.speaker: LYS.
speech.line: Ha’ you done?

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: My lord, she’s not pac’d yet, you must take some pains to work her to your manage. Come, we will leave his honor and her together. Go thy ways.

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: I beseech your honor one piece for me.

speech.speaker: LYS.
speech.line: Avaunt, thou damned door-keeper!
Your house, but for this virgin that doth prop it,
Would sink and overwhelm you. Away!

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: How now, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: Worse and worse, mistress, she has here spoken holy words to the Lord Lysimachus.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: O abominable!

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: She makes our profession as it were to stink afore the face of the gods.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: Marry, hang her up forever!

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: The nobleman would have dealt with her like a nobleman, and she sent him away as cold as a snowball, saying his prayers too.

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: Boult, take her away, use her at thy pleasure. Crack the glass of her virginity, and make the rest malleable.

speech.speaker: BOULT.
speech.line: And if she were a thornier piece of ground than she is, she shall be plough’d.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Hark, hark, you gods!

speech.speaker: BAWD.
speech.line: She conjures, away with her! Would she had never come within my doors. Marry, hang you! She’s born to undo us. Will you not go the way of womenkind? Marry, come up, my dish of chastity with rosemary and bays!

speech.speaker: GOW.
speech.line: Marina thus the brothel scapes, and chances
Into an honest house, our story says.
She sings like one immortal, and she dances
As goddess-like to her admired lays.
Deep clerks she dumbs, and with her neele composes
Nature’s own shape of bud, bird, branch, or berry,
That even her art sisters the natural roses;
Her inkle, silk, twin with the rubied cherry,
That pupils lacks she none of noble race,
Who pour their bounty on her; and her gain
She gives the cursed bawd. Here we her place,
And to her father turn our thoughts again,
Where we left him, on the sea. We there him lost,
Where, driven before the winds, he is arriv’d
Here where his daughter dwells, and on this coast
Suppose him now at anchor. The city striv’d
God Neptune’s annual feast to keep, from whence
Lysimachus our Tyrian ship espies,
His banners sable, trimm’d with rich expense,
And to him in his barge with fervor hies.
In your supposing once more put your sight:
Of heavy Pericles think this his bark;
Where what is done in action, more, if might,
Shall be discover’d, please you sit and hark.

speech.speaker: TYR. SAIL.
1. GENT. TYRE.
speech.line: Doth your lordship call?

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: Gentlemen, there is some of worth would come aboard;
I pray greet him fairly.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Gentlemen, Sailor of Tyre and Sailor of Mytilene.

speech.speaker: TYR. SAIL.
speech.line: Sir,
This is the man that can, in aught you would,
Resolve you.

speech.speaker: LYS.
speech.line: Hail, reverent sir! The gods preserve you!

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: And you, to outlive the age I am,
And die as I would do.

speech.speaker: LYS.
speech.line: You wish me well.
Being on shore, honoring of Neptune’s triumphs,
Seeing this goodly vessel ride before us,
I made to it to know of whence you are.

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: First, what is your place?

speech.speaker: LYS.
speech.line: I am the governor of this place you lie before.

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: Sir,
Our vessel is of Tyre, in it the King,
A man who for this three months hath not spoken
To any one, nor taken sustenance
But to prorogue his grief.

speech.speaker: LYS.
speech.line: Upon what ground is his distemperature?

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: ’Twould be too tedious to repeat,
But the main grief springs from the loss
Of a beloved daughter and a wife.

speech.speaker: LYS.
speech.line: May we not see him?

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: You may,
But bootless is your sight; he will not speak
To any.

speech.speaker: LYS.
speech.line: Yet let me obtain my wish.

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: Behold him.
This was a goodly person,
Till the disaster that, one mortal night,
Drove him to this.

speech.speaker: LYS.
speech.line: Sir King, all hail! The gods preserve you! Hail, royal sir!

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: It is in vain, he will not speak to you.

speech.speaker: LORD. MYT.
speech.line: Sir,
We have a maid in Mytilene, I durst wager,
Would win some words of him.

speech.speaker: LYS.
speech.line: ’Tis well bethought.
She questionless with her sweet harmony,
And other chosen attractions, would allure
And make a batt’ry through his deafen’d parts,
Which now are midway stopp’d.
She is all happy as the fairest of all,
And with her fellow maids, is now upon
The leavy shelter that abuts against
The island’s side.

stagedir.dir: Gives an order to a Lord, who goes out.

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: Sure all effectless; yet nothing we’ll omit
That bears recovery’s name. But since your kindness
We have stretch’d thus far, let us beseech you
That for our gold we may provision have,
Wherein we are not destitute for want,
But weary for the staleness.

speech.speaker: LYS.
speech.line: O sir, a courtesy
Which if we should deny, the most just God
For every graff would send a caterpillar,
And so inflict our province. Yet once more
Let me entreat to know at large the cause
Of your king’s sorrow.

speech.speaker: HEL.
speech.line: Sit, sir, I will recount it to you,
But see, I am prevented.

stagedir.dir: Enter Lord with Marina and a young Lady.

speech.line: I will desist,
But there is something glows upon my cheek,
And whispers in mine ear, “Go not till he speak.”

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: My fortunes—parentage—good parentage—
To equal mine—was it not thus? What say you?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: I said, my lord, if you did know my parentage,
You would not do me violence.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: I do think so. Pray you turn your eyes upon me.
You’re like something that—What country-woman?
Here of these shores?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: No, nor of any shores,
Yet I was mortally brought forth, and am
No other than I appear.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: I am great with woe, and shall deliver weeping.
My dearest wife was like this maid, and such a one
My daughter might have been. My queen’s square brows,
Her stature to an inch, as wand-like straight,
As silver-voic’d, her eyes as jewel-like
And cas’d as richly, in pace another Juno;
Who starves the ears she feeds, and makes them hungry,
The more she gives them speech. Where do you live?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Where I am but a stranger. From the deck
You may discern the place.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Where were you bred?
And how achiev’d you these endowments which
You make more rich to owe?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: If I should tell my history, it would seem
Like lies disdain’d in the reporting.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Prithee speak.
Falseness cannot come from thee, for thou lookest
Modest as Justice, and thou seemest a palace
For the crown’d Truth to dwell in. I will believe thee,
And make my senses credit thy relation
To points that seem impossible, for thou lookest
Like one I lov’d indeed. What were thy friends?
Didst thou not say, when I did push thee back—
Which was when I perceiv’d thee—that thou cam’st
From good descending?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: So indeed I did.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Report thy parentage. I think thou saidst
Thou hadst been toss’d from wrong to injury,
And that thou thoughts’ thy griefs might equal mine,
If both were opened.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Some such thing
I said, and said no more but what my thoughts
Did warrant me was likely.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Tell thy story;
If thine, considered, prove the thousand part
Of my endurance, thou art a man, and I
Have suffered like a girl. Yet thou dost look
Like Patience gazing on kings’ graves, and smiling
Extremity out of act. What were thy friends?
How lost thou them? Thy name, my most kind virgin?
Recount, I do beseech thee. Come sit by me.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: My name is Marina.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: O, I am mock’d,
And thou by some incensed god sent hither
To make the world to laugh at me.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Patience, good sir!
Or here I’ll cease.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Nay, I’ll be patient.
Thou little know’st how thou dost startle me
To call thyself Marina.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: The name
Was given me by one that had some power,
My father, and a king.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: How, a king’s daughter?
And call’d Marina?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: You said you would believe me,
But not to be a troubler of your peace,
I will end here.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: But are you flesh and blood?
Have you a working pulse, and are no fairy?
Motion? Well, speak on. Where were you born?
And wherefore call’d Marina?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Call’d Marina
For I was born at sea.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: At sea! What mother?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: My mother was the daughter of a king,
Who died the minute I was born,
As my good nurse Lychorida hath oft
Delivered weeping.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: O, stop there a little!

stagedir.dir: Diana appears to Pericles as in a vision.

speech.speaker: DIA.
speech.line: My temple stands in Ephesus, hie thee thither,
And do upon mine altar sacrifice.
There, when my maiden priests are met together
Before the people all,
Reveal how thou at sea didst lose thy wife.
To mourn thy crosses, with thy daughter’s, call
And give them repetition to the life.
Or perform my bidding, or thou livest in woe;
Do’t, and happy, by my silver bow!
Awake, and tell thy dream.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Celestial Dian, goddess argentine,
I will obey thee. Helicanus!
Shall we refresh us, sir, upon your shore,
And give you gold for such provision
As our intents will need?

speech.speaker: LYS.
speech.line: Sir,
With all my heart, and, when you come ashore,
I have another suit.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: You shall prevail,
Were it to woo my daughter, for it seems
You have been noble towards her.

speech.speaker: LYS.
speech.line: Sir, lend me your arm.

speech.speaker: PER.
speech.line: Come, my Marina.

scene.scenelocation: Ephesus. Before the temple of Diana.

speech.speaker: GOW.
speech.line: Now our sands are almost run,
More a little, and then dumb.
This, my last boon, give me,
For such kindness must relieve me:
That you aptly will suppose
What pageantry, what feats, what shows,
What minstrelsy, and pretty din,
The regent made in Metelin,
To greet the King. So he thrived
That he is promis’d to be wived
To fair Marina, but in no wise
Till he had done his sacrifice,
As Dian bade; whereto being bound,
The interim, pray you, all confound.
In feather’d briefness sails are fill’d,
And wishes fall out as they’re will’d.
At Ephesus the temple see,
Our King and all his company.
That he can hither come so soon
Is by your fancies’ thankful doom.

stagedir.dir: Enter Pericles with his Train: Lysimachus, Helicanus, Marina, and a Lady.

speech.speaker: GOW.
speech.line: In Antiochus and his daughter you have heard
Of monstrous lust the due and just reward.
In Pericles, his queen and daughter, seen,
Although assail’d with fortune fierce and keen,
Virtue preserv’d from fell destruction’s blast,
Led on by heaven, and crown’d with joy at last.
In Helicanus may you well descry
A figure of truth, of faith, of loyalty.
In reverend Cerimon there well appears
The worth that learned charity aye wears.
For wicked Cleon and his wife, when fame
Had spread his cursed deed, the honor’d name
Of Pericles to rage the city turn,
That him and his they in his palace burn;
The gods for murder seemed so content
To punish, although not done, but meant.
So, on your patience evermore attending,
New joy wait on you! Here our play has ending.
